Award.AwardTitle: Mass spectrometric based analysis of plasma membrane proteins that regulate cell expansion in Arabidopsis thaliana.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Molecules present in the outer membranes of cells act as antennae to perceive changes in the environment, and transmit this information into the cell by chemical reactions (for example phosphorylation) and by changes in shape (or conformation.) Newly developed technologies allow such conformational changes in molecules to be detected using the methods of mass spectrometry, and in this project these new technologies will be used to understand how signals regulate the rapid expansion of plant cell size. Exercises will be developed for high school students, using mass spectrometry to analyze common food proteins such as soybean tofu. A PBS television series "Wednesday Nite at the Lab" that is broadcast free from the University of Wisconsin Biotechnology Center will explain to the general public (and demystify) mass spectrometry, using as an example the analysis of plant proteins and explaining how this impacts their everyday lives.

Overall this project seeks to combine in vitro and in vivo approaches to understanding the molecular basis for signal transmission across the plasma membrane. The focus of this project is Feronia, a plant plasma membrane receptor kinase, and its peptide hormone ligand, RALF. When RALF binds to the extracellular domain of Feronia, the rate of cell expansion is reduced within minutes. This project will develop and apply novel mass spectrometric based tools for analyzing the conformational changes that extracellular RALF induces in Feronia. The newly devised PLIMB instrument (Plasma Induced Modification of Biomolecules) that generates microsecond pulses of hydroxyl radicals will be used to "footprint" Feronia and other proteins that are involved in Feronia/RALF action at the plasma membrane.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since plants cannot move away from stressful conditions, they have developed exquisitely sensitive methods for detecting changes in their environment, and adjust their rate and direction of  growth accordingly. Plasma membrane receptor proteins act as the molecular 'antennae' that perceive changes in the cell wall and the external environment, and continuously transduce this information to the interior of cells, such as the cytoplasm and nucleus. In this study we have developed and applied sophisticated instrumentation and technologies for studying the structure of these proteins.  Much of this work involves the use of mass spectrometers, which are expensive analytical devices that help us analyze changes in the chemical properties of the proteins. Sophisticated chemical analyses using mass spectrometers play a crucial role in modern genomic research. These instruments are playing increasingly important roles in common life, from airport security screens to robotic laboratories on Mars.  To help teach the public and educators why basic research with sophisticated and expensive instrumentation is a critical part of our society the we have employed the UW Biotechnology Center's (UWBC) outreach staff with an established record of providing educational opportunities and activities for the community at large. For example, we have developed and implemented high school exercises using mass spectrometry to analyze and assess the authenticity of commonly raised Wisconsin food proteins, such as tofu from soybeans and milk from cows. To share our enthusiasm for basic research with the general public we have also expanded presentations in our television series, 'Wednesday Nite at the Lab', broadcast for free from the UW Biotechnology Center via public television (PBS).  Overall, we have thus utilized a three-pronged approach to enhance the broader impact of our work: (1) produce high-impact research that benefits basic science, (2) develop high school-focused curriculum to 'demystify' mass spectrometry, and provide students with hands-on experience and (3) promote public engagement via lectures broadcast online and on PBS TV.
